awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Teachpad - A Teach-to-Learn Paradigm for Difficult Math Concepts
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to use current research in the learning sciences to develop games that make middle school math engaging and relevant.  Middle school is a crucial time in a student's educational journey as it is the period at which their self-concept of ability becomes stable. Studies show that it is also the period at which students start getting disengaged with math and there is a marked increase in negativity towards math from sixth to eighth grade. According to the National Report Card, only about a third of 8th graders in US public schools, of over 3.6 million students, score at the proficient or above level in Math every year. The goal of this proposal is to implement and test the effectiveness of a scaffolded learning and teaching environment, called the 'Teachpad', that helps middle school students learn difficult math concepts. Multiple studies have indicated that students put more effort into learning when they have to teach someone else. This project will extend these studies and evaluate whether the teachpad increases student engagement and improves learning and long term retention of difficult math concepts.

The proposed project uses a "teach to learn" framework in which students teach characters in a computer game how to solve specific problems and use the feedback that they receive from the characters to evaluate how well they have understood the concepts themselves. The teachpad uses natural language input, meaning that the students can enter their instruction in plain English and can explain the solution to the problem as they would to a friend or sibling. A semantic parser extracts the useful information from this input and feeds it to a machine learning algorithm to teach a game character how to solve the problem. A model of what the character has learned is also visible to the student who can see how their instruction is working when the character is trying to solve a test problem. This project will implement the teachpad for the order of operations, and will determine how it compares to traditional classroom practices. Data will be  collected in authentic educational environments, through observations and interviews to study student engagement and usability, and pretests and posttests (once after the treatment and once when students return from summer break) to evaluate learning outcomes and long term retention.

por.por_cntn:
According to the National Report Card, only about a third of 8th graders in US public schools, of over 3.6 million students, score at the proficient or above level in Math every year and of even more concern is that a third of the students score below the basic level every year. Middle school is a crucial time in a student?s educational journey as it is the period when their self-concept of ability becomes stable. If during this time, students make up their mind that math is hard, boring, or irrelevant to their lives, then they are always going to believe that they are not a ?math person.' Also, algebra is the gateway to all higher level math classes and eventually to college and a majority of career choices. There are a huge number of subjects which require knowledge of algebra, like biology, chemistry, physics, engineering, computer science, economics, medicine, psychology, and social sciences. Unfortunately, it is also a gatekeeper because students who do not acquire proficiency in Algebra are prevented from pursuing higher education or a career in STEM and many other fields.  Our goal is to use the genre of adventure games to bring relevance and engagement to algebra and other middle school math areas, and to use the research in the learning sciences and the latest technology to develop games that can help every student succeed in learning math.

 

Our phase 1 proposal was to design and develop a teach-to-learn component (teachpad) that was to be a part of an adventure game. In the teachpad, the student was asked to teach a character in the game how to solve a problem. The goal of the teachpad is to help students learn difficult math concepts. Our initial proposal centered on how a  student?s natural language input can be used to instruct a game character to do a problem. However, although we were successful in developing the teachpad for one math concept, we decided that it was not a very scalable model, and decided to focus our efforts on the adaptive scaffolding that we were developing as a part of the teachpad. The Xpert notebook is an intelligent adaptive and deep scaffolding that determines if a student has the foundational proficiency for learning a particular concept and if they don?t, helps them acquire that mastery.

 

The feasibility study for the Xpert Notebook was carried out at a private school in San Francisco. The sixth-grade class had 20 students and but by the day of the test, only 18 students had turned in their permission forms. However, we administered the study to two individual students who had responded to our call for participants in a local newsgroup. We administered a pretest with 2 straightforward questions and 2 transfer questions to the students. The first 2 questions of the pretest were similar to the questions in the number lock (Fig 1) while question 3 was similar to the review question (Fig 2).

 

In the first 2 questions in the pretest, 6 students answered both questions correctly, and 7 students got the first easier problem right, but the second problem wrong. In the number lock, after they?ve had a chance to use the Xpert notebook to learn, 15 students did all 3 problems correctly, 2 students got 1 question right, but didn?t finish, and 3 students didn?t start the problems. The number of students who got the correct answers doubled even though the problems themselves were more difficult in the number lock. However, it could also partially be because, in contrast to the paper test, the game environment allowed the students to redo problems that were wrong whereas in the paper test they did not know whether they were right or wrong. A more reliable test would have been to give them a paper-based post-test as well, which we were not able to because of time constraints.

 

Our goal was to determine the technical feasibility of including this smart scaffold in an adventure video game to make the game an adaptive learning environment and to test the effectiveness of this attempt. Our phase 1 research has shown that it is feasible and can potentially have a significant effect on learning outcomes.
